summary: The code defines a table of file types with their common names, generates shorter/more common terms for each, and applies the appendnow function to create Table0. It creates a table for file handles, reads data from each handle, and uses Lua's `io.popen()` to execute external commands and combine results.

details.comment: The code defines a table containing various file types and their common names. It then iterates over the table to generate shorter and more common words for each file type, storing them in Table0. The function map_all applies the appendnow function to each element of the original table, appending the shorter/more common terms into a new string which is added to Table0. Finally, it can be seen that there is an intention to print out the contents of Table0 but it has been commented out.
details.content:
Table={
	[1]={"pdf","document","doc",""},
	[2]={"reader","conver","format",""},
	[3]={"txt","text","word",""}
}
--shorter, and more common is better.
--not even the whole word.
Table0={}
spliter="---------fuckyou---------"
function map_all (fcn, tab, idx, ...)
    if idx < 1 then
	    --count of the list.
	--print("--spliter--")
	-- this is the print-them-all function.
        fcn(...)
	--print("--spliter--")
	-- it is appending the thing on the back of argument list.
    else
        local t = tab[idx]
	-- length minus one.
        for i = 1, #t do
		--print("--spliter0--")
		map_all(fcn, tab, idx-1, t[i], ...) 
		--print("--spliter0--")
	end
    end
end
function appendnow(...)
	local shit=""
	for fuck,nothing in ipairs({...}) do
		if nothing~=""  then
			shit=shit.." \""..nothing.."\""
		end
	end
	if shit~="" then
		Table0[#Table0+1]=shit
	end
end
map_all(appendnow, Table, #Table)
--[[for x ,v in ipairs(Table0) do
	print(v)
end]]
handle={}                                  for key,value in ipairs(Table0) do
	command ="apt-cache search"..value

details.comment: This code creates a table to store file handles and reads data from each handle, then prints the results along with some additional information. It uses Lua's `io.popen()` function to execute external commands and capture their output. The purpose is to gather information by executing multiple commands and combining their results.
details.content:
-- no trailing space.
--psudocode above.     
	handle[#handle+1]= io.popen(command)       --is it threaded?                  
end   
for key,value in pairs(handle) do
	result = handle[key]:read("*a")
	handle[key]:close()                        -- use local instead of using some functions.
--	print (result)
	print(Table0[key])
	print(spliter)
	io.write(result)
	print(spliter)
end
